message: I am currently busy grading today's assignment papers. If you have any questions, please write them down and bring them to me.

replies.text: Never mind, that's quite a hassle.
[Guess I'll find some paper and ink...]

message: Sigh. My friends convinced me to run to the bakery for some snacks, and now I'm stuck in this dusty room doing extra tasks because I was late to class.
Shh, I don't need any additional punishment for chit-chat.
I would rather work on these terrible assignments than be in that Feygard professor's history class.

replies.text: Can you tell me who this professor is

message: His name is Frederich. He was sent here as a teacher after Lord Geomyr took the throne. Though that was long before I came here. I only heard about it from my upperclassmen.
Excuse me, but I don't have time to play around. Can't you see that I'm studying?
Welcome to Alain's General Store and Warehouse. Is there anything you need?
I'm in the middle of an important ritual. If you require something, please consult with my steward, Stiyl.
If those Feygard folk are anything like him, you'd better steer clear.

replies.text: Hmph, another peasant who doesn't understand the glory of Feygard.

message: [You see a young girl sitting at the table with her arms resting on it and her head lowered.]
[Upon closer inspection, you notice the girl is fast asleep.]
Even so, the shadow most certainly watches over you.
Hello there, child. Are you perhaps interested in following the shadow?

replies.text: Could you provide me with supplies?
I'm searching for my brother, Andor. Have you seen him?
How do I follow the shadow?
Bah, all this shadow stuff--what a bunch of nonsense.
I've visited the chapel, and for a town of this size, it's surprisingly small.
Can you tell me the story about the chapel again?

message: I'm sorry, there are many students from the academy frolicking, and their faces are not imprinted on my memory.

replies.text: Can you tell me how to follow the shadow?

message: May the shadow assist you on your journey
The shadow speaks to us. It watches over our thoughts, and guides us.
To follow the shadow, one must listen to its voice and direct their gaze toward its wisdom.
Walk the path of one's destiny, and as the challenges upon your journey unfold, follow the guiding voice of the shadow.

replies.text: Thanks, may the shadow be with you.
None of this makes any sense, but sure.

message: Hey kid, come and drink with us!
Greetings, my name is Fiamma. I forge my swords as finely as I bake my bread.

replies.text: Could you show me what you have to sell?
That makes it sound like you're not a very good baker either.
I have the lava rocks and arulir skin.
I have the Red crystal here.

message: Greetings, my name is Fiamma. I forge my swords as finely as I bake my bread. How can I help you.
Halt! If you value your life, stay off this path, kid.

replies.text: Ha, I can handle myself. Don't worry about me.

message: Sure, kid. You do seem to be carrying some shiny equipment. Just don't blame me if you get eaten by a scary lizardman.
If you go that way, all you'll find is a shack, some trees, and the mountain. What's really scary are the nasty lizardmen who occasionally stumble up on the shore.
Terrifying, humanoid creatures with blood-red scales instead of skin, and the head of a giant Erumen lizard.
Bye, kid. Take care, and don't slack off in school, or else you'll end up slaying sewer rats down in Nor City. [laughs]
Just the thought gives me shivers.
Behind it, lies a story.
In the past, the people of Brightport used to worship the Shadow at the Great Water Temple.
But twenty years ago, calamity struck. A race of Erumen lizards, uncannily similar to us in form but beastly in nature, engulfed the islands of the lake.

The temple was ransacked, and not a single one of its acolytes or servants returned. The nobles, now as back then, are still preoccupied with trifling matters. I'm afraid we will never reclaim our holy place.

replies.text: Could you tell me more about the lizardmen?
Is there something I could do to help?
Thank you for telling me this story.

message: They carry crudely made weapons and have distinctive blood-red scales, and would attack travelers along the shores of the Bright Lake.
I have heard stories from adventurer's of lizardmen with scales of different colors, displaying more reason than the red-scaled ones, but stay safe my child.

replies.text: Thank you for telling me this story.
Thank you, shadow be with you.

message: Shadow embrace me!
Shh child. Look. [The man points at the altar]

Hey kid, have you met my brother outside? Haha, that guy's a real Scrooge, they say we're nothing alike,  I'm telling you. He's just like Mom - We'd ask her to tell us a bedtime story, and she'd have us pay for it with shiny stones or rainbow beetles. Hic. Speaking of bedtime stories..

replies.text: Im afraid if I let you speak it will never end.

message: I once heard a story about a guy who visited a kingdom ruled by rats - They call it the Ratdom! Haha! People say he disappeared as a child and reappeared a decade later, wearing clothes made entirely of ratskin. He even spoke Rattish! Imagine that, speaking Rattish! Hic. speaking of rats...

Those folks from Brimhaven! - I'd refrain from rudely calling them... hmm, mice. But if anyone resembles a mouse, it would be them. We got a job offer from.. Hic. I'm professional enough not to reveal our clients... Long story short, we ended up declining due to a failure in negotiations. The client then went and hired some local, incompetent bunglers to handle the delicate job! Should've seen it coming, considering we wouldn't budge on the price. Speaking of price...

replies.text: Interesting, but i must go now.

message: Speaking of "never end" I was assigned to a job a while ago, up in the north. On my way there, I encountered a small critter. Eager for some fresh meat, I slew it, but what came next was, quite literally, never ending. A whole group of large beasts were watching me, as I was flaying the skin off the beast. Once I was distracted enough, they came pouring out of the bushes. I could maybe count a hundred before I went running! I left the meat behind, and even dropped my heirloom skinning knife. Speaking of knives...

replies.text: Interesting, but i must go now.

message: Sigh. It's almost time for my shift again, but I can't complain. The guild pays good money.
Keep yourself safe.
Welcome! Is there something I can help you with?

replies.text: Could I rent a place to rest?

message: I'm sorry, at this time of the year, we get a lot of visitors, and all the beds are occupied.
Sigh. Nowadays, the streets are always bustling with clamor, and everyone seems to be in a hurry. I miss the days when I could quietly sit and gaze at the lake.
Excuse me, I have no time for discussion.
Hello, kid. My name is Counterfeit. I specialize in exactly that. Now, please leave me be, I have work to do.

replies.text: I need a copy of the key for the library here in Brightport. Could you help me with that

message: Normally, I'd need the original, but lucky for you, kid, I was a student here years ago and made a copy. You can have it, for 500 gold.

replies.text: I don't have that gold on me.

message: Alright, here you go. Now hush off. I've got work to do.
[The golem is quietly tending to its chores]
Hello there, $playername. My name is Silvear. I'm a merchant of sorts, though my merchandise is a bit, unorthodox.

replies.text: What is it that you sell?
How do you know my name?
How do you know my name?

message: Hello, $playername. Any news?

replies.text: What is it that you were selling again
Can you tell me about Andor again?

message: Though, you might be interested in what I know about your brother, Andor.

replies.text: Andor is my dear brother, i will do whatever it takes to find him, tell me what you know.
Of course I am! That damn kid has caused me so many problems that I want to find him and smack him in the face.

message: I have many ears. I know who you are, and that you are searching for your brother.

replies.text: That doesn't make me any less suspicious of you. So, what is it that you trade?

message: I know the names of my fellow guild members, yours especially.

replies.text: That doesn't make me any less suspicious of you. So, what is it that you trade?

message: I specialize in trading information, rumors, stories, and the like. not something I could sell to a kid like you.

replies.text: It happens that Im interested in the local Guard commander. Can you tell me anything about him?

message: As I mentioned, I'm a merchant. I can tell you about Andor, but it will cost you. Say, 500 gold.

replies.text: Hey,  I've already paid you once!
For my brother it is worth that much.
I don't have that gold on me.

message: That amount shouldn't be too difficult for an adventurer like you. I'll be waiting.
Thanks for the business kid.
I've known your brother since his days as a student here at the academy. We spoke a few times; he was mostly interested in speaking to the boss of our guild here in Brightport. That's all.

replies.text: I need to talk with your boss then, where can I find them?

message: Can't complain when you're the one asking, kid.

replies.text: I don't have that gold on me.

message: Our boss? let me think.
I already told you where to go, kid. Head inside and use the entrance in the back. Thanks for the free gold, though
For you, it'll be 2,000 gold coins. It's our hideout, kid, I can't just give out access for free.

replies.text: That price seems a bit excessive "for me". I've done a lot for the guild. I'm the one who took down Crackshot.
I can guarrantee you a lot of trouble if you don't let me in, for free.
The only thing wider than my purse is my patience for the likes of you. [pay him the gold]
I don't have that gold on me.

message: You won't get far with that attitude. Come back when you've grown up a bit.

replies.text: [He is right, that was childish of me.]
[Tch, if we weren't inside a town, I could show him.]

message: Sure, that was impressive for someone your age, but what goes down in Umar's turf has little to do with the guild here in Brightport.

replies.text: [Bluff] Must I remind you that the profits from Fallhaven's guild deals with Sullengard, are also reaching the guild here in Brightport?
Argh, fine, let's return to the previous conversation.

message: OK OK. fine, I apologize, the guild's policy is for me to inform new members and useful visitors of the hideout for free.
The entire fee thing was my own idea. please don't tell the boss.
To find our hideout, head inside via the door on the right, then check behind a stool in the upper left corner. best of luck to you kid.
Go inside through the door on the right. In the upper left corner, you'll spot a protrusion in the wall, that's where you'll find our hideout. Bye, kid.
Hello, and welcome to the world famous bakery of Brightport, how may I help you?
[The mass of dough is slowly pulsating]
Please stay away from the bread; you will mess up the leavening process.

replies.text: Yuck, that looks nothing like bread.

message: Welcome to Brightport's armorsmithy, how can I assist you?
Hi kid, Im Janus the armorsmith, if you want some brand new equipment you would do right to visit my house.

replies.text: I've already did, and spoke to Freya.

message: Is that so? I'm glad my lovely wife runs the shop while I take a break. I hope you enjoyed what my craftsmanship had to offer.

replies.text: I loved them, but my enemies won't.
Quite decent for a backwater town.

message: Hello, today's astronomy class at the Academy. Will be held in the evening, you musn't miss it.

replies.text: I don't have time to attend classes, I must find my brother Andor.

message: That boy Andor? he was a bit unremarkable but he had a real passion for astronomy. What has happened to him?

replies.text: He has been missing for a while, and so my father sent me out to search for him. Have you seen him?

message: I'm afraid I cannot be of much help. I haven't seen Andor since his days at the Brightport academy. I hope you find him soon.
It is surprising for someone visiting Brightport not to know about its Academy. Head to the western part of town, and you will find it.

replies.text: I don't have time to attend classes, I must find my brother Andor.

message:
The man looks at you with a hunter-like gaze, giving you a slight shiver.] 

A kid like you shouldn't be here.

replies.text: What's with this dog next to you?

message: I can read the naivety off your face. A kid like you will just be used to do someone's dirty work.

replies.text: I'm old enough to be responsible for my actions. I do what is right to me.

message: Im Oseanpry, a hunter, and the guild's cook. I've hunted the deer of brightport for many years. until the boss hired me to hunt for people.

replies.text: Do you have any food for sale?

message: Very well, but remember, each of your choices has consequences. Once made, you won't be able to go back to how things were before.
Yes, like you did with Ambelie, and just like you, I was also searching for someone close to me... but I can't speak about it now..

replies.text: Intriguing, but I have to go now.

message: I came here for the pastries, and it was completely worth it! These apple pies are so good, I could die!
I've just been to the bakery, and it left a sour taste in my mouth! Those apple pies are so bad, I could die!
Hello, my name is Elynard, I came here from a beautiful village called Luthaven. You should visit it sometime.
Where did I put my glasses? Was it here... or maybe over there?
Oh, it's you, Andor! Even without my glasses, I can tell you haven't changed a bit. Here to visit Stanwick, I see.
He's at the academy, as always. Here, take these fruits with you and give them to him for me, would you?
Welcome to the Brightport Academy. I'm Dibella, the principal's assistant.
It's the time for the history lecture. If you hurry, you might still make it to the lecture room on time!

replies.text: My brother has been missing, so I'm here to ask his friend Stanwick for a clue on his whereabouts. Could you tell me where I can find Stanwick?
I have this batch of fruit that Janwick asked me to bring to his grandson in his stead.
Could you tell me about the incident again?
Could you tell me what know about the library theft?

message: Is there something I could assist you with?

replies.text: My brother has been missing, so I'm here to ask his friend Stanwick for a clue on his whereabouts. Could you tell me where I can find Stanwick?
I have this batch of fruit that Janwick asked me to bring to his grandson in his stead.
Could you tell me about the incident again?
Could you tell me what know about the library theft?

message: Have you not heard of it? Stanwick is on strict house arrest following the recent library incident. No one is allowed to enter his room except for his roommate and family.
Let me see... that should be fine. I can make an exception if Grandpa Janwick asked you.
Go via the hallway on the left until you reach the dorms, Stanwick's room is the second door in the middle.
Oh, I thought you were a student here. My memory must be mistaken.
Several days ago, Headmaster Oswald discovered that an extremely important document went missing from the basement archive of the library.
Stanwick looks after the library, so after questioning the teachers and students, the Headmaster decided that Stanwick would stay in his room until the end of the investigation.

replies.text: What was soo important about this document anyway?

message: Im not aware, my job entails depositing paperwork in the archive, not reading it. Any necessary document I keep in my desk. Besides, the important documents are locked in a box that only the principal is allowed to open.

replies.text: [If I recall, Stanwick was living here in Brightport with his grandfather. I should seek him out.]

message: Ah, this deer soup smells just heavenly.

replies.text: Could you sell me some traveling supplies?
Excuse me, could you please tell me what you know about the library theft?
Soup from those creepy deer? Yuck.

message: I'll read it next after I'm done with this other paper. Please come back later.
I've read your question, but I must say, your handwriting could use some improvement.

replies.text: Hey, if you slayed dragons like me, you wouldn't have time to practice either.
Tsk, skip to the answer part please.

message: I haven't read your question yet. Come back later.

There is not much I can tell you about the incident. None of us teachers knew anything about the scroll or where it was kept. In such a case, one could presume that the most logical step would be to investigate the room where it was kept.
However, the library was locked, so one would need to ask the principal for permission.
I take it you are looking to help your friend Stanwick. Very well.
Stanwick is an honor student. But the importance of a secret document passed down to each generation's headmaster far outweighs his merits.

As the library supervisor, he performed his duties very well. Unfortunately, that put him closest to the theft. Both his grandfather and the town council approved of the decision. That is all I can say.
No sorry, the dining room is for students only.
I don't know much about it, to be honest. I'm just the cook. But...

A longer time ago than the incident, even before the last graduation class, one evening I was preparing the soup stock for the next day when I noticed a dark figure going outside from the direction of the dormitory.
I assumed that I was just tired and didn't give it much thought. I told the headmaster, but it didn't seem to be related to the theft. That's all.
[You see a young boy of about age 16 sitting on a chair and reading a book.]
[He notices your presence and looks at you, his face quickly turning into a smile.]
Long time no see, $playername! What brings you to Brightport? Did Andor finally convince you to enroll, or did you just come to see me? [The boy laughs.]

replies.text: Ha, not in a thousand years! You guys were always making me run errands.
I was getting bored back home with nothing to do!

message: Yeah, I bet. Crossglen can be pretty boring, but it's also nostalgic.
Someone had to go buy the bread, and pull the weeds. And it wasn't going to be us.
I have ink and paper on me, I should sit down at one of the tables and write my question.
You sit down at the table and pull your ink and paper out of your bag.
Hmm, what did I want to write about again?

replies.text: We're in a classroom, so evidently, a scholarly question!
I should write down my question regarding the theft.
Evidently. a tale of my adventures!

message: Did you see my broth-, no, that's not it. Hello, have you see- Argh! [You crumple the paper into a ball and toss it aside.]
[After a few rows of written words, you quickly realize the daunting task ahead of you and promptly give up.]
How do I cook meat... Well, that's not exactly a scholarly question. [You crumple the paper and toss it away.]
I ran out of paper. I should go and buy some more.
Silly me. I was going to write a note asking Professor Franz about the theft. Having fun makes you get carried away.
[You manage to write down the question without wasting any more paper.]
Hey, kid, stop running around my office! You're distracting me from my work.

replies.text: Excuse me sir. I wish to help Stanwick by investigating the theft. Could you tell me more about it?

message: How unfortunate to be stuck inside, when the sun's soo dazling.
Hey kid, any progress on finding the scroll?

replies.text: I have the scroll here, take it.
If I could investigate the library, I could find something.
Sir, what's that thing looking at us from the window?

message: Still, though, it's been a while, huh? Six years since my father sent me to Crossglen for safety, when I met Andor and you.
By the way, did Andor accompany you here? I was hoping I could ask for his help on something.

replies.text: Andor has been missing, and I was sent here to search for him.

message: That's terrible news. But strangely, I'm not that surprised, something about his behavior before graduation was bothering me.

replies.text: That might be something that could help my search. Could you tell me more?

message: I wish I could, but now's not the right time. This incident that's happened has left my memory in a haze.
At this rate I will be freed of suspicion, but if they don't find the stolen document while im still on room arrest, my reputation might never recover.

replies.text: I heard of the incident. I could help you with it.

message: Several days ago, I was attending to my duties in the library when Headmaster Oswald came in to access the archive. When he returned, he was in a panic about a missing document.
Of course, I had nothing to do with it. As a matter of fact, the Headmaster and his assistant were the only ones I've seen go down there.
You would? But still, I'm not sure. This might be as difficult as finding a needle in a haystack.

replies.text: You can trust me. I've solved all sorts of mysteries on this journey.

message: Thank you $playername, Im convinced I can entrust this to you.
OK. You should start by asking people around the academy. maybe it will send you in the right direction. Good luck.
How's the investigation going, $playername?

replies.text: Do you know how I can enter the library?
Could you explain to me the details surrounding the incident?
I found and returned the document to the headmaster, he'll release an apology for you later.

message: I gave the principal my library key. You should try asking him.

replies.text: I already did and he refused to give me the key.

message: Shortly after, every senior student, and teacher were gathered in the lecture room for questioning. No one knew much about it, so it was over quickly. Afterwards, the headmaster decided I would stay in my room until the end of the investigation.

replies.text: Wasn't that a bit too rash?

message: All things considered, it was a reasonable response. The safekeeping of the archive was partly my responsibility. But being told to stay put while I could have done something to help find it, does feel deeply unfair to me.

replies.text: I'll see what I can do.

message: Hmm, let me think.

I once accidentally damaged an expensive book cover. To get it fixed, I turned to someone nicknamed Counterfeit from the Brightport thieves guild. He managed to restore it in no time. You should try asking him for help.

replies.text: Where can I find the thieves guild?
I know exactly where to look.

message: It's against the rules to tell, try asking a man named Silvear, you'll recognize him by his blue cloak.
Thank you $playername. I knew I could entrust this to you.
Hey $playername, how is your search going?
[Stanwick lets out a deep breath, his expression softening with visible relief, as he sits down on his bed.]
A visitor, how unusual. I presume you haven't simply stumbled upon my cabin by accident.

replies.text: Are you the person named Bryma?
Yuck, what are those things behind your cabin?

message: Forget it. This is none of your concern. What makes you think you should be involved?

replies.text: It's unfair that Stanwick, whose name is most to suffer from the theft, was told to stay put.
I made a deal with Stanwick. I scratch his back, and he scratches mine.
Nothing. I wish to help out of the kindness of my heart.

message: You sound like trouble, kid. Take my advice and stick your nose somewhere else.
Those who are eager to help with nothing to gain are usually the most vicious bunch. At least I can take your word on that, kid.

I admit that this decision might put Stanwick's future employment in Nor city at risk. But the safety of the academy comes first. I am sure Stanwick is innocent, but we can't be safe enough, when it comes to matters as this.

If the lord in charge of the town of Brightport learns of the contents of the scroll, we will be accused of treason, heads might roll, and our town's standing will be greatly diminished. Do you understand what's at stake now?

replies.text: Yes, it was a reasonable action.
That still doesn't make it right.

message: Very well then, I accept your assistance on this matter. report back to me on your findings.
Then you have some growing up to do.
I had no expectations of you in the first place. now stroll along.
I won't allow it. If this is as far as you go with the investigation, then so be it.
[You notice a key on a shelf under the desk, if he were distracted for a moment you could steal it]

replies.text: [There has to be a different way.]

message: [The headmaster look in the direction of the window. For a moment he is distracted.]
I won't fall for the same joke twice. Find something better to do with your time.
That's not funny, there was nothing there.

replies.text: It was probably a bird, must have flew away, probably.
At your age poor eyesight's not uncommon.

message: You rummage carefully through the shelves and drawers, eventually spotting something unusual. A bundle of papers tied together with twine, tucked behind a stack of old records.

You untangle the bundle and read through some of the letters. They seem to be correspondence addressed to the past headmaster. Finally, you find one that reads: "A request for the headmaster in regards to the secret recipe."

[Headmaster Dervin, the potion you rewarded me with for the results of my research has proven to be far more effective in the leavening of bread than the normal bonemeal potions I used. I cannot understand what it might contain. May I request to borrow the scroll containing the recipe to finalize my results?]
Signed, Bryma.

replies.text: This seems to be from many many years ago. It would not be odd if both the writer and recipient were old or in their graves.

message: Hello, young fellow. Want to hear a story?

replies.text: You must have been living here for a long time, right?

message: Do you know why the houses in Brightport that are closest to the shore of the lake, have foundations made of stone?

During the normal time of the year, the creek which flows through Brimhaven ends up draining into the mountain. But when the rainy season starts, the water becomes a monstrous maelstrom, filling the mountain basin and overflowing down onto the plains and into the lake.

That, and the confluence of other rivers east, which drain into the lake, causes the water level to rise and flood the grasslands surrounding the lake. It reaches up until the foundation of the houses but never rises more than the second stair step.
Ho, ho, what resplendent blue waves.

replies.text: Can you please tell me that story again?
You must have been living here for a long time, right?

message: It would be my joy, young fellow, but first.
Yes, I have seen Brightport change. I've lived through its tumultuous times. Why do you ask, young fellow?

replies.text: I'm looking for a person who lived here a long time ago, named Bryma. Have you heard of them?

message: That's a name I haven't heard in more than 20 years!
She was my student, and like many youngsters, she aspired to make a name for herself, and became a researcher. But one day, she decided to leave Brightport, and I have not heard from her since.

replies.text: She might be my only clue to solve a problem. Is there really nothing you can tell me about her whereabouts?

message: Hmm, it sounds like you've found yourself in some kind of argument. If it helps, she left a plethora of her writings and research at my house for safekeeping. You can read through them. I hope it proves helpful.
You open the chest hoping to find the writings of Bryma that Richimor spoke about.
Let's see... This one's a recipe for milk bread. This one's the same, but with wild berries...

You read another writing, which immediately strikes your attention.

[My findings of four mysterious statues, outside Brightport. in the north south and soutwest. upon the utterrance of the activation phrase..]

The writing abruptly ends and there doesn't seem to be much description other than that, almost as if they decided to keep the details a secret. No matter how it's related, it's worth finding out.
I hope my shift ends soon! I was staring at the surface of the lake when I spotted a pair of yellow eyes looking at me from under the surface!
I'm Gunfryk, the guard commander. Inform me or my men if you spot any trouble.

replies.text: Can you tell me more about your job?
My friend got chased by a lizardman and he went inside the derelict house east, please save him! [Lie]
I heard word you really love Orchids, Sir Gunfryk. [Blackmail the commander.]

message: [An invisible force prevents you from moving further.]
Hey kid, you might be right about the swords, but don't ever insult my baking skills!
Unfortunately, it's not about my skill but the quality of the steel. If I had the materials, I could forge good swords all day.

replies.text: If I brought you the materials, could you forge me something with them?

message: All the metal we're getting now is lower quality scraps. There's a shortage, but Feygard has also been deliberately affecting the trade, so that blacksmiths in towns which were affiliated with Nor City can't forge quality weapons. Keeping all the good ore to themselves.

replies.text: What would you say if I brought you some quality materials?

message: OK. First, we have to discuss the materials I have in mind. I presume you have heard of the town of Remgard?

replies.text: Yes I have heard of it.

message: If so, then listen closely, as you are about to hear of it.

Many travelers pass through Brightport on their way to and back from Remgard. The town lies high in the mountains, and from those travelers I heard of beasts called arulirs, harassing travelers along a short stretch of the road.

But what's most interesting is their origin. The area they now inhabit was a mining camp, which was abandoned after the caves became unstable. Out of the depths, gornauds clawed a tunnel, releasing arulirs from the fiery depths they inhabited.

First, if you can travel there, I want a strip of the arulir's skin - rumored to be tougher than steel but as flexible as leather. Second, I want 15 lava rocks from inside the mountain cave. These will fuel my forge better than the brown coal.

And lastly, the material from which I will forge a blade, a red crystal from a gornaud. This material, which their teeth and claws are made of, can easily crush rock. Only in rare cases, the mineral gathers and forms crystal clusters on their body or inside them. So don't be disheartened if you seemingly can't find one. Good luck!.
Yes, those look good. thanks!
Wow. it looks magnificent!
With all these quality materials, I can forge you something magnificent enough to equal the legends. Come back to me later!
What a clear crystal! but I still need the lava rocks for fuel, and the arulir skin. bring them to me and I can start.
Remember, I still need that red crystal to forge the blade. Bring it to me, and I can start.
It's done! but.. There is a slight problem.
The sword is not done yet. Have you no patience?
I've quenched it, but when I try to pull it out of the water, it reacts to the air and starts heating up. It quickly becomes unbearable to hold.

I was hoping to keep the Arulir skin for a pair of forging gloves, but I ended up making these smaller. heat-resistant gloves to wield the magnificent two-handed sword I crafted from the materials you brought me.

replies.text: Two-handed sword? I thought you would make me a normal sword.

message: Hey, you didn't specify, so I made what I know best.

replies.text: Could you forge me something else with the same materials then?

message: Frankly, I don't feel like forging another sword for you, but I can give you something else instead, and keep the sword for myself if you don't like it.

replies.text: Sorry, i'll keep the sword instead.

message: Well, kid, usually I would have my reservations about giving someone as young as you something this dangerous. But you're the one who fought those dangerous creatures, so my worries are unfounded. Take it, and use it well.

replies.text: [I'll probably keep it as a trophy]

message: Here, take this glaive, it was given to me by my old master from Nor City. it was originally forged for nobility but after lord Emeric's defeat in the noble wars. The Imeria branch of house Houdart, fell from grace, and this was sold for cheap at an auction.
Before you stands an imposing stone statue, overgrown with moss.

After a bit of examination you notice something engraved on the statue. Symbols similar in appearance to the letters L and H.

The lines are straight and the shapes are a bit hard to tell but these must be letters. I should keep them in mind.
Before you stands a crumbling stone statue, hidden behind the foliage.  and overgrown with moss.
Before you stands an imposing stone statue, overgrown with moss.

After a bit of examination you notice something engraved on the statue. Symbols similar in appearance to the letters G, A and R.

The lines are straight and the shapes are a bit hard to tell but these must be letters. I should keep them in mind.
Before you stands an imposing stone statue, overgrown with moss.

After a bit of examination you notice something engraved on the statue. Symbols similar in appearance to the letters T and E.

The lines are straight and the shapes are a bit hard to tell but these must be letters. I should keep them in mind.
Before you stands an imposing stone statue, overgrown with moss.

After a bit of examination you notice something engraved on the statue's base. Strange symbols unlike any you have seen before.

Straight and cluttered lines. they don't look like any of the symbols you know. next to them is a an odd pictogram

                                           *            

*                 
                                   #
                                                   *
Now that I discovered the rest of the statues. I should spell the letters to form the activation word.
It's probably related to the activation word, I should find the rest of the statues.
That didn't seem to have had any effect.

That seemed to have been the activation word, as the statue lightly shone

I can probably go inside the forest now.
[The Headmaster hurriedly grabs the scroll and opens it to confirm its contents. A moment later, he breathes a sigh of relief as he moves it over the flame of a nearby candle.]
You've truly saved my skin- I mean, the people of Brightport! Yes, ahem.
Before we discuss what is next. Have you learnt who the culprit of the theft was?

replies.text: It was my brother Andor. He stole it many months ago, and gave it away in exchange for forbidden knowledge.
I prefer not saying, it would cause trouble to the people who helped me.
A former baker named Bryma was in possesion of it. How she acquired it im unaware.

message: Your brother you say.. That is quite serious. I have heard from Dibella that you are searching for him. If you find him you must put in all the effort that he turn away from his malicious ways.

As I suspected, it was someone interested in its contents. Anyhow, that name is of little importance to us now. The academy's priority should be increasing the security of the library, and we'll start by changing the archive's lock.
If that is what you say, then so be it. What matters is that the Achilles' heel of our academy was removed without further damage. This oversight on my part will not be repeated.

And now on the matter of Stanwick. The school will release him an apology letter, and I will personally make sure this had no lasting impact on his reputation. Please tell him that he is free to leave his room.
Please have these Deerskin gloves as a sign of my gratitude. Those are as sturdy as far as leather can go.
Oh, and I almost forgot..
Stealing the key was not very nice of you. Consider your reward the fact that I overlooked it this time.
Goodluck on your search. Bye.
It's an odd coincidence that the only 2 visitors I have had in years are asking the same question. You two could almost be twins.

replies.text: So you are Bryma then. I'm looking for a document from the brightport archive that was stolen.
Could that possibly have been my brother Andor?

message: Andor? yes, I think that was his name.

You mean the secret scroll that I have right here? 

[Bryma takes out a rolled, tettered looking parchment]

replies.text: You can give it to me, or I can take it by force.
I need to bring it back, could you kindly give it to me?

message: He brought me a scroll that I was interested in many years ago, in exchange for teaching him forbidden alchemy techniques. but by his tone I knew it was not something I had a choice on.

replies.text: I was looking for that scroll, can I have it?

message: Is that any way to speak to someone you just met? soo rude! - Here, have it, I wasn't intending to keep it anyway. And if you return, leave that attitude outside my cabin.
It was never my intention to keep it. as It's not particularly useful to me. Here, take it.

replies.text: Thanks! I will make sure it's returned to it's place.

message: You're back again? The forest isn't as quiet as it used to be.

replies.text: Can you tell me more about what you know of my brother Andor?
Can you tell me about Andor again?
I encountered a strange creature in the cave under your house. It didn't stick around though.
I heard you haven't been in Brightport for years, how did the scroll reach you?
What's with that statue at the entrance of the forest?
Why do you live here in the forest?
You mentioned your bonemeal research, what can you tell me about the potion?
Can you tell me about your bonemeal theory again?

message: Those are the bread golems I managed to create after years of research and study, with the great minds of Nor city.

[ The upper part of the sign has been scratched off]
East: Brightport
South: Duleian road
Hello, and welcome to the world famous bakery of Brightport, how may I help you?
I would gladly forge you something, but it would require much effort on your part. If that's alright with you.

replies.text: There is no task beyond my skill.
Ha! you're speaking with a seasoned adventurer, I can do it!

message: It was brought to me by a boy who looked a lot like you.

About half a year ago, I was carefully measuring the ingredients for my baking experiments when I heard the door. I went to look and, a boy of about 17 introduced himself. I think his name was Andor..

We sat down, and he started asking me all sorts of questions. I was glad to have someone to talk to. But soon, he pulled out a list of ingredients and asked on how to acquire and use them, most of which were highly poisonous.
I tried to refuse him, but that's when his tone shifted. The cheerful charisma he'd shown vanished. As he pulled out that scroll, I heard him mumbling, 'Last measure...'

I had no choice. I told him everything he wanted to know. And he left me with the scroll before leaving.  It might have been useful to me 20 years ago, but i've already researched past it to develop my own baking theory.

replies.text: Can we talk about something else?

message: About half a year ago, I was carefully measuring the ingredients for my baking experiments when I heard the door. I went to look, and a boy of about 17 introduced himself as Andor.
Sure, what do you want to know?

replies.text: Can you tell me about Andor again?
Why do you live here in the forest?
What's with that statue at the entrance of the forest?
You mentioned your bonemeal research, what can you tell me about the potion?
Can you tell me about your bonemeal theory again?

message: I discovered this place in my youth while researching Brightport's fauna. After Lord Geomyr's coronation, fearing I might be arrested for my bonemeal research, I came back, patched things up, and moved in. It's pretty cozy - I can drink tea and bake at my leisure.
At the start of my baking studies, I set out to develop a unique leavening method to stand out from other bakers and make a name for myself.
I tried using different yeasts, temperatures, and moisture levels, but none gave me the results I was hoping for. That's when I decided to mix a bonemeal potion into the process.

Many things, but mostly on bonemeal potions. their healing potency and various properties left me puzzled for many years. I studied them with the great mind of Feygard and Nor city alike, until the bonemeal ban.

replies.text: What does that have to do with baking?

message: To my amazement, the bread rose to nearly triple its size! That's when I brought it to the headmaster's attention. It was greatly received, and I was rewarded with a specially made bonemeal potion from his collection.
But the bread baked from that one started mutating, much like what you can see in my kitchen. Soon afterward, my research was barred, and I soon left Brightport of my own volition.

replies.text: Can I ask you something else?
Thanks for telling me this story. I will be on my way.

message: Don't underestimate baking, child. To master this art takes years of arduous training, including advanced alchemy. Even I struggled at first.
It will be a long and difficult subject, so please keep that in mind and don't interrupt me, but first.
Woof.
[The dog wags it's tail]
She is my loyal hunting partner. We've been through thick and thin.

replies.text: Wow! can I get one too?

message: What?! No way kid, dogs are notoriously hard to tame. now hush off!
Move it kid, I've got work to do here.
Please keep off this path, you'll get under the feet of the workers.

replies.text: What's up with all these crates outside?

message: I am Eatloni the storemaster. My brother Allares and I handle the storage and delivery of the bakery's goods.

replies.text: Is there any work for me to do here?

message: Our bakery bakes the finest bread in all of Dhayavar. Of course, there's bound to be a bit of a jumble getting it onto the rich folk's tables.

replies.text: Is there any work for me to do here?

message: You're better off asking my brother Allares, you can find him in the bakery. Either way, they sure do make you youngsters work hard these days, huh.

[It steps back cautiously, its claws scraping the stone floor.]

Human again? Why come here, not welcome. Leave.

replies.text: I mean no harm. Bryma said your kind's been troubling her, so I came to find out why.
I was just out for a stroll, and you bolted like your tail was on fire. Thought I'd see what all the fuss was about

message: I'm not mad, but entering people's homes isn't exactly a nice thing to do, you know.
Grandfather? well, yes, but he's outside at the moment.

replies.text: Thanks, that's all I needed to know.

message: What do you think makes bonemeal so desirable, even three years after its ban?

replies.text: It's cheap and offers the best treatment against ailments.
Personally I don't know, that evil concoction hasn't been anywhere near close to my mouth.
The ingredients to make it are easy to find anywhere.

message: I don't know whether to applaud your commitment or waive it off as a form of childish ignorance, but either way..
That is true, any ordinary tomb will do for some bones.. and monsters are not an uncommon appearance in our day and age.

The correct answer would be all the correct reasons you could cite. It's cheap, it's effective, and it worked for hundreds of years. But if you think I'm a supporter of its consumption, you would be wrong.
That would be close to the most correct answer but it's not it.
In the first place, don't you think there's something off about it? It's easy to make, cheap to consume, and immensely effective.
Not to mention the origin of those bones could have very well been from humans, and there have been stories of such things being done, especially during plagues. Nevertheless..

replies.text: I thought we would be talking about your research?

message: Oh  right, my apologies. I got a bit sidetracked. Yes, where do I begin.

In my baking research, I discovered that the potion does not merely heal but it facilitates growth. What we perceive as healing is, in fact, simply the acceleration of your body's natural regeneration condensed into a shorter time by the potion.

But my experiments revealed something more. The late Headmaster Dervin rewarded me with an advanced bonemeal potion. that contained a mysterious ingredient called kazarite, which doubled the growth factor of a regular bonemeal potion.

This completely changed my perspective. When I asked for the recipe to identify the ingredient responsible, I was denied. But this was no setback. I soon realized that bones are not unique in their properties. It's common alchemical knowledge that monster parts are prime ingredients for potions, but my discoveries went even further.

I call this the Theory of Essence. We all know that when the Rift opened, immense magical energy entered our plane along with the monstrous creatures. Before that, what I refer to as the essence already existed, but it was greatly strengthened by the Rift.

This essence exists within every part of Dhayavar. The soil, the mountains, the creatures, and the people all hold it. The proof lies in the crystals that form inside monsters. These crystals are concentrated forms of essence. Bones are another place where essence gathers most densely. The essence is our world itself. When we take in more of it, we restore what we lose through disease or injury.

Not to say it's all the same. Some things, despite containing high essence, can be harmful to us, such as poisons, or diseases, which drain our lifeforce. Merely consuming more has no benefit, and indeed there have to be certain attributes or balance. But nonetheless, there is much to explain. I was working to publish this among the scholars of Feygard before the bonemeal ban.

replies.text: Can we talk about something else?
That's too much to digest. I'm gonna have to go now.

message: Those statues are intriguing. The 'Lethgar' password refers to the Lethgar people, but they lived over 2,000 years ago. There's little chance the statues are that old. How the barrier works remains a mystery.

replies.text: Can we talk about something else?

message: Ho ho, younglin', how goes the day? coughs Don't mind me, just speak your piece.

replies.text: Sorry, I've got nothing to say.

message: Im Rubiano, the Doughe of Brightport, speak up.

replies.text: Have you seen my brother Andor?
What's the history of the town?

message:
Your brother, you say? Let's see..."

[Rubiano pulls out a small folder from his desk and starts browsing through it, muttering to himself.]

Andor, Andor...
The Doughe is the one who oversees Brightport, much like a mayor. The title is chosen by the council from among the De Lucent family, as we've guided the township's administration since its founding.

replies.text: Begging your pardon, but are you of noble blood, Sir?

message: Haha, don't sweat it, kid! We're Brightporters, like any other. So, what brings you here?

replies.text: Have you seen my brother Andor?
What's the history of the town?

message: I see an Andor listed here, graduated from our academy half a year ago. He left Brightport then. Has he not made it back?

replies.text: He has, but he went missing recently, so my father sent me out to search for him.

message: Braving these lands for your brother, impressive. You have courage. May the shadow watch over you.
Brightport was founded by my ancestors over 700 years ago. Sir Lucient of House De Lucent and his loyal squires were the first to set foot on this shore of the Bright lake.

First, they built the manor, followed soon after by the bakery to sustain the house's trade. The squires and their families became the first commonfolk, joined over the centuries by merchants who chose to settle and make Brightport their home.

We of the De Lucent family have been guiding the town ever since. But regrettably, the past Doughe, my father, was executed by decree of the king for having sided with lord Emeric of Nor city. Since then, we've had to answer not to the king directly but to a foreign nobleman ruling over our lands.

replies.text: Thanks for telling me this story, I'll be on my way.

message: Have you had any success with the creatures?

replies.text: As long as you don't bother them again, things should be good now.
I've met with the leader of the lizardman tribe, they demand I return the 20 stolen bones.
I've yet to return the bones.
I returned the bones but I've got one more task to do.

message: Lizardmen, again. They've been bothering me for months now. My bread golems can handle a few, but if they all come at once, I'll be in trouble.

replies.text: Guess, I could help with that, what's the story here?

message: One day, I ventured into that decrepit basement to see what's around. Curious, I began exploring and carelessly ventured down into a cave. days later, I began hearing the scratching of their monstrous claws echoing through the tunnels. Likely a warning. This repeated until one day I went down to check and the passage was blocked with rubble.

replies.text: I'll see what I can do about those creatures.

message: I appreciate your enthusiasm. The passage down is blocked but if you go deeper inside the forest you'll find another statue. the activation word is "Light" please use it to find a way to their nest.
As you walk down the cave tunnel, you abruptly stop in your tracks as you notice a mysterious creature standing a stone throw's away from you you.
[The mysterious creature leaps through the rubble to the other side of the cave.]
Before you stands an imposing stone statue, overgrown with moss.
The statue lightly shone.

[The lizardman hisses as it notices you entering the chamber. Its piercing yellow eyes narrow.]

You chase me, why? Speak quick, or claws do the talking.

replies.text: I mean no harm. Bryma said your kind's been troubling her, so I came to find out why.
Chase you? I was just out for a stroll, and you bolted like your tail was on fire. Thought I'd see what all the fuss was about.

message: Bryma, that name stinks of lies! You call us trouble, but never ask why? Always blaming, never listen.
She took what's not hers. Bones of our elders, sacred to us! We try to recover them, but she sends beasts. You call us trouble? She's the trouble!

replies.text: I didn't know that. Maybe we can come to a compromise?
I've had enough of your rambling. [Attack the creature.]

message: You! you smell of the witch. The witch who brought trouble!
I haven't talked with the creature yet.

[As you attempt to strike at the creature, it swiftly evades your blow. But unsurprisingly, your combat experience comes on top, grazing its body. However. The spot it had moved to avoid your attack had put it closer to the entrance, allowing it to leap into the cave opening with precise nimbleness.]

No! But.. I am only Emyro, the scout. I refuse, but leader must decide. Find our home, and leader Elyzard will tell...
[The lizard cautiously steps back, then leaps out the entrance of the burial cave.]
[As you make your way to the settlement, you freeze in your step, a loud hissing sound resounding in your ears.]
Your days end here, troublesome intruder.

replies.text: I will polish my blade in your blood.
It's not too late to apologize..

message: Despicable creature, you show before us. your days end!
You are welcome here, but don't overstep boundaries.
Outsider, speak to leader Elyzard.
I am watching you, outsider.
I have heard from Emyro. You come before me, but there can be no talk before you return what the witch stole!

replies.text: I swear to return what was taken from you, what should I do?
I've changed my mind, we will talk with our swords!

message:
[The lizard king's advisor interjects]

Minion of the witch. From our burial chamber 20 bones of our ancestors were shamelessly stolen. return them to us or we return them ourselves.
Suffice to say, those bones are no longer around, I ground them to dust for my bonemeal research and fertilizer experiments.

replies.text: Great, and what am I suppossed to return now?

message: No need to look at me like that, if those bones are gone just find more to replace them with.
Red or green, their bones look the same. Just slay those red ones along the shore of the lake until you have enough. Here's a few of what I've got left  for starters.
I see, good luck with that.
That is no problem. But how am I supposed to get bones now...

replies.text: I negotiated with the lizardmen, they agreed to trade you the bones of the animals they hunt.

message: You've done a great job $playername. It's a shame I don't have much to offer you, please take these special bonemeal potions. I can't trade you more, but I can give you these 2.
And I also wish to mention, from Brightport towards Charwood, there used to lay a path traders would take, However an unknown happening led to the awakening of a nearby statue, which barred the path.
The activation word for that specific statue is "Lethgard" I hope that information assists you well, take care.
It is good to see you $playername. what brings you around?

replies.text: I wish to talk about something.

message: Sigh, I didn't expect you to pick such a violent method. But please finish the work to the end, there are still lizardmen left.
Good work $playername. Now I have access to as much bonemeal as I need. please have these potions including a special one.
I've slain the leader of lizardmen, I should move on to his lackeys and the rest of the tribe.
With this, the whole tribe is wiped out, I should return and tell Bryma.
Outsider, have you returned with the bones?
We thank you outsider. But not enough to repair our trust.
Speak with Dominio our Shadow chaplain, he will tell you the task.
You are worthy of our trust now, but don't overstep, outsider.

replies.text: Can you tell more about the lizard people?

message: Carry out your task, outsider. Don't dissapoint.
Our ancestors, been inhabiting the bright lake for many generations, until you, men without scales, drove us away to the mountains.
Us men with scales acknowledge strenght, and accept defeat. But mountain have little food, so we fought eachother and separate. We came here, others swam north. And we created many tribes.
Many, but what remains are three great tribes. Us green-scale, Honorable brave warriors, the lineage of heroes.
Yellow-fang, greedy and cunning. love to eat gold and steal.
And the barbaric red-claw, violent and slowminded, never listen to reason.

replies.text: You're not friends with them? oh phew.

message: Help the shadow Chaplain with task, only then our trust be restored.

replies.text: I helped Dominio with his task.

message: Praise. Honorable! you promise and deliver, much admirable.
Before you stands a mysterious red crystal, the likes of which you vaguely remember having seen before.

replies.text: Strike at the crystal with your weapon

message: You strike the crystal as hard as you can, the impact sending a jolt of pain through your body.
You havent left as much as a mark.
Kazaul thu'um kha'zan
As soon as you strike the crystal, it reverbrates. Shattering into countless pieces, leaving behind only a pile of rubble.
As soon as you strike it, the crystal reverbrates. Shattering into countless pieces, leaving behind only a pile of rubble. - With this both crystals are destroyed.
As soon as you strike the crystal, it reverbrates. Shattering into countless pieces, leaving behind only a pile of rubble.
As soon as you strike it, the crystal reverbrates. Shattering into countless pieces, leaving behind only a pile of rubble. - With this both crystals are destroyed.
You returned the bones of our people back to us, shadow be with you, human.

replies.text: The chieftain told me, you have a task for me.
Why is a shadow priest in this place?

message: Our tribe was proselytized many years ago by the honorable paladins of Nor City. We were given the Holy Book of Rites, which I relentlessly study to enlighten my people.

replies.text: Finally someone who can speak properly, can you tell me more?

message: I see you are longing for the wisdom of the shadow, but you have been sent to me with a purpose, is that not the case?

replies.text: The chieftain told me you have a task for me.

message: I don't trust you outsider, leave.
Our trust is given, what else do you wish to ask for, outsider.

replies.text: Would you agree to trade Bryma the bones of the animals you hunt?

message: As long as she doesn't intrude on us, it is agreed. Now go and rest well, we welcome you.
The statue lightly shone.
You are welcome here, outsider. Rest well.
Yes. But outsider, this is no mere task.  Every man who has sought to prove themselves to our tribe have been tasked with this challenge, but none have succeeded.
West of our village lies the entrance to a ruin from which at times beasts of darkness emerged to attack our village.
We have drove them back numerous times, but past the entrance no lizardman can pass, a force holding us back. The only ones able to being humans.
Over hundreds of years, adventurers have failed to slay the beast or claimed to have done so, but the attacks continued, leaving us to distrust your brethren.

However. The last human to challenge the ruin was a man named Lutarc. He slayed the beasts and brought back two stone tablets, which shone light on the origin of those creatures. They are not mere animals, but guardians that will manifest as long as the magic maintaining the millennia-old ruins is still active.

The source of that lies in two crystals within the ruins. From the two tablets, I uncovered that the key is chanting a specific phrase before them. We need you, human, to finish this centuries old task.
Good, the specific phrase you must chant is "Kazaul thu'um kha'zan" after that deliver a solid blow to these crystals, report back to me if this truly works. May the shadow watch over you.
Shadow welcome you, outsider. How is the task?

replies.text: I found those crystals and shattered them.
What am I supposed to do again?
It might be too tough for me now, I'll attempt later. [leave]

message: Remember, find the 2 crystals inside the ruins to the west, and try to break them.
Great, and what about the beasts?

replies.text: After the crystals shattered they too, did.

message: That is wonderful news! Please tell the chief about your deeds, and hopefully my tribe's attitude to the outsider and the shadow change. Shadow be with you.
Shadow welcomes you, friend.

replies.text: How did the shadow end up in a place like this?

message: Who in Dhayavar are you? you better get out of here before we mess you up.
How's my hair? And is my skirt straight? I just want to make sure everything looks okay before I go to class.
Buzz off kid, I'm feeling a bit too sick for class today, let me read the valorous knightly stories of sir Wormgand in peace.
You've got a reason to be here? Yeah right, get out of here kiddo.
Yeah Yeah, get out of here!
Wait, wait Barthold! isn't that the kid?
What, who?
It's the kid Benbyr wrote us about, remember?
Oh yeah, kinda does look like the one he wrote us about.
I was convinced you were sent to spy on us. So, what brings you around here.

replies.text: Im looking around the town searching for my brother.
Benbyr said to come see you.

message: Really, what does he look like?

replies.text: He looks a lot like me, his name is Andor.

message: Benbyr did? Ha! I guess that guy's still up for business! - Say, you want to work for us?

replies.text: The kind of work that sent Benbyr to jail? No thanks.
Im not sure, what kind of work exactly?
Sure, I have a history of getting things done.

message: Hmm, doesn't ring a bell.
Hey Dynes! have you seen this Andor guy?
Dunno, beats me.
You heard him kid. Sorry we have nothing to help you with. Anything else?

replies.text: Benbyr said to come see you.

message: It's nice to see a trustworthy fellow like you around. So, you need something?

replies.text: Im looking for my brother Andor, have you seen him?
Benbyr said to come see you.

message: That's the spirit!

Don't lump us in with him, Benbyr's greed got the best of him, he started dealing with rather questionable merchandise. On the other hand we're not doing anything illegal, just inconvenient for those stuck up guards.

replies.text: Inconvenient enough that you can't do your work anymore, sound like illegal to me.

message: We have some deliveries to do, we're under watch and can't receive more merchandise, but if we had a new face do it for us we could totally manage it.

When the honorable people of Nor city arrived here and requested our assistance in battle, we obliged under the condition that they must cleanse the ruins of the beasts. While the warriors were away I was taught of the Shadow by the priests of the group.

This mausoleum was comissioned by Sir Rolton of house Ryfarion, for the sacred keeping and memory of the valiant warriors of Nor City. 

May the Feygard scoundrels rot beneath the cursed swamp.
Looking for wor
Listen kid all our goods are legal, But they want us to pay those things called "taxes" and listen to their "Trade restrictions" Completely ridiculous! So you in to work for us or not?
Yeah I don't think you should speak to me about that, bye.
Well now, a familiar face, but you're not the one im familiar with. Pleased to meet you, $playername. I must admit, you do bear a striking resemblance to him.
Well, well, if it isn’t one of Umar’s little helpers. Did Umar run out of work for you, or are you just sightseeing?

replies.text: I heard my brother Andor came to speak with you before. I was hoping you could tell me about your meeting with him.

message: I was expecting your visit. Umar wrote to me that you would come. $playername
I can't tell you much that you haven't already heard from Umar, but there is a single detail that might intrigue you.
Who are you, and what do you need from us?

replies.text: What do you do around here?

message: Hmm, on second thought, I would feel bad about giving you that kind of responsibility, Gunfryk's men are ruthless, if you get caught, you'll have no peace in Brightport.
He is the Guard captain, Brightport used to be a hub of smuggling, well, we still are. But Gunfryk has significantly stopped it, His men pay no heed to bribes or the Shadow.
Unless you could travel to Feygard and speak with Lord Emerion im afraid not my child.

replies.text: Thanks for telling me the story, I will be on my way.

message: Yeah, he really threw a wrench in our cogs, that guard outside was put there to watch on us for a year now. We've only managed to stay afloat thanks to some of the merchandise we've hid away in a cave.

replies.text: I would rather not put myself at odds with the Feygard soldierly, bye. [Leave]
Then all that it takes should be getting rid of him.

message: That's a dangerous thing you're saying, there is no way you can do that. He's not exactly a sheep, Gunfryk is a skilled and cunning warior.
Yeah you'd have to be more discrete, we don't want thing to go in a worse direction. If you can pull it off we'll reward you handsomely but if you fail you've got nothing to do with us, understand?
Dangit Dynes don't egg on the kid. Killing is off the list understood? Just make him less of our problem.

replies.text: Got it, I'll "make" him not be a problem, heh.
How else can I deal with him then?

message: I don't know, you're our sheep culling expert here. But surely Gunfryk has some secrets he wishes to hide.
We protect Brightport from the critters of the wilderness and barbaric monsters such as those lizardmen. -  All by decree of our king, Lord Geomyr.
With us around all those Nor city thugs are shaking in their boots, Brightport has never been safer.
Lizardman you say? that is extremely serious, I will call my men and we will hurry on to save him!
Hey kid, any news on your task?

replies.text: It was a hard fight, but I killed him, I made it look like a lizardman attack.
Good news. The commander’s going to be turning a blind eye to your deals for a while. [Show him the compromising records.]
I tried to but I couldn't do it, sorry.

message: You mean Gunfryk? He’s after the rougher thieves, the ones who step outside Feygard law. Never bothered my work, so I don’t bother his. But his guards? They gawk at me like hawks too.

replies.text: That's interesting but I need something.. That I could use.

message: I do have something on him in case our current arrangement ever went sour, but you would have to do a good job of convincing me to hear it.

replies.text: I can't pay you a lot without being sure if the information will help me, best I can do is this. [Offer 500 gold]
Im getting rid of your biggest problem without you lifting a finger, Is that not good enough?

message: We've talked about this before. Im confident in my skill, the information I possess will be enough, With that in mind 1500 gold is sufficient.

replies.text: Fine, have your price. [Give him the gold.]
I don't have that much gold on me, I'll be back later.

message: Pleasure doing business with you.
I would do better to put my trust in Gunfryk dying of old age, $playername. My plans I carry alone, your plans you better pay and 1,500 is my asking price.

replies.text: Fine, have your price. [Give him the gold.]
I'll be back when I have the money. [Leave.]

message: When he arrived here and some of my acquittances were sent to the Feygard prisons, I had to collect some information for safety measures. Our guard commander here had a habit of visiting a certain "establishment" in Nor city, here are the records.
Rest assured, I would not risk my contingency on shoddy information, with that in mind 1,500 gold sound like a better price.

replies.text: Fine, have your price. [Give him the gold.]
I'll be back when I have the money. [Leave.]

message: What? [The commander gulps dryly.] Who told you that? Plus my favorites are crysanthemes!

replies.text: I also heard you love rolling on the flower fields and smelling the roses, I think the others would also love hearing that. [Wave around the records of him visiting a flower shop.]

message: Grr, this is blackmail. I get it. What is it? What do you want?

replies.text: You've put my two acquittances, Dynes and Barthold in a tough spot with your rules, I would appreciate it if you gave them some leeway, unless you want others to hear about your "activities"

message: Have it your way! just don't tell my men about my hobbies, my reputation would be ruined. But don't think this will last for long!
You killed him!? You're really tough! -  But him dead. That's not ideal
What’s wrong, Barthold? With Gunfryk dead, we’ve got free rein!
Free rein? It bought us time. Even if it looked like a lizardman attack, there is no guarrantee the replacement Feygard will send won't be someone more extreme.
Anyway, here is your reward kid, with skills like yours you would surely find more work to do for our friends in Nor city.
Is your friend safe kid?! I sent my men to the abandoned manor and they caught a Nor city spy, but no trace of any lizardmen or your friend! [The commander extends his arm to grab your shoulder.]

replies.text: Umm. Ermm. He is alright sir.

message: I should find a spot behind those crates to lie in wait.
Just a bit more waiting....
[You hear the heavy thuds of several armored men approaching from outside.]
Men, prepare yourselves!
Sir, I don't see anything could it be hiding?

replies.text: That would be me. [Jump out to attack]

message: Phew. Job well done!
Show me that! [Barthold skips through some of the pages with a confound expression.]

Ha ha ha ha! - That's soo funny, who would have guessed that stern Feygard dog would have such hobbies, and in Nor city nonetheless! - Feygardians and their pride, he surely wants to avoid his men from finding out.
And for a job well done here is your reward, rather generous I say. You would surely find more work to do in Nor city, just tell them Barthold sent you.

replies.text: If not information on my brother atleast some gold.

message: Then that is good, and if not for you we wouldn't have went there and found that spy, well done.
